content: The "Gerardo Hernandez Airport Security Act of 2015" requires airports to have individualized working plans for responding to security incidents within the airport perimeter. The Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security will provide technical assistance to ensure compliance. The "Gerardo Hernandez Airport Security Act of 2015" mandates airports to have specific plans for responding to security incidents within the airport perimeter, such as active shooters and acts of terrorism. These plans may include strategies for evacuating and caring for individuals, establishing a unified command, testing communication equipment, and ensuring prompt emergency call responses. The airport security plan should include communication methods, projected response times for security incidents, joint training schedules, after-action reports, and access to video surveillance for law enforcement. The Assistant Secretary will report to Congress on airport security preparedness and disseminate best practices for security incident planning, management, and training across airports. The Assistant Secretary will certify that all screening personnel have participated in active shooter training exercises within 90 days of the Act's enactment and annually thereafter. Additionally, the Assistant Secretary will provide an analysis on using cost savings to enhance security measures to Congress within the same timeframe. The Assistant Secretary will use cost savings to increase funding for checkpoint screening law enforcement support agreements over the next 5 years. They will also conduct outreach to high-risk passenger transportation agencies to ensure they have plans in place to respond to security incidents targeting passengers, including evacuation and care strategies for individuals, especially those with disabilities. The Assistant Secretary will report to Congress within 180 days on findings from outreach to agencies and providers regarding security measures for individuals using the transportation system, including unified command, active shooter training for frontline employees, testing of communications equipment, and expeditious handling of emergency calls. The Assistant Secretary will report to Congress on the level of preparedness of transportation systems to respond to security incidents and disseminate best practices for security incident planning, management, and training. No additional funds are authorized for this Act, and an interoperability review will be conducted within 90 days. The Assistant Secretary of the Office of Cybersecurity and Communications will review the interoperable communications capabilities of law enforcement, fire, and medical personnel at all US airports for responding to security incidents. A report on the findings will be submitted to the House Committee on Homeland Security and the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation within 30 days.
